channel.title: Package Managers Comparison
channel.description:
I had to write a website for technical writing, so I chose this topic and I thought I would share it with everyone.
http://moparisthebest.com/pkgmanager/index.html
Please give me feedback here, whether it be criticism, corrections, or even reviews for other package managers that I can add to the site.

item.title: Package Managers Comparison
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:17, topic:195356”]Ok, thanks. I will look into both of those further and update the site when I get some spare time.

sppt, I thought sabayon added an extra layer on top of portage to handle binary packages, you are saying binary package ability is built into portage? If so, out of curiosity was it always like this?[/quote]
as far as i know, it has always been into portage, but most are reluctant to use it because of several reasons

Read full topic

item.title: Package Managers Comparison
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

mopar, if you would spend some more time with portage, you would probably know that you can use binaries, you just need to set up the BINHOST var in /etc/make.conf

Read full topic

item.title: Package Managers Comparison
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:13, topic:195356”]Ok, I have fixed the few errors, made the comparisons page validate correctly, and changed the banner image.

Onto the ABS/makepkg thing, is it the equivalent of dpkg’s source packages? or is it the equivalent to checkinstall? which when executed instead of the ‘make install’ command builds a deb or rpm package?[/quote]

More similar to the latter. Basically, with makepkg you create a “PKGBUILD” file which describes how the source is to be compiled and the information on the package, such as name, dependencies, what it provides (ie which dependencies it fulfills). Then, you run makepkg on this PKGBUILD to create a binary archlinux package which can be installed via pacman. It’s the package creation process, it’s just really really simple so that you can use it to create packages whenever you need to install something from source.

On top of that, Arch provides the AUR, which is a repo much like the pacman repos but for source packages (PKGBUILDs) - fully community provided.

If you don’t want to faff around with makepkg, you can get a pacman front-end called “yaourt” which offers a one-command install from the AUR/source.

Read full topic

item.title: Package Managers Comparison
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Indeed, you completely overlooked the fact that ABS+makepkg are designed to be used in conjunction with pacman to provide from-source packages - or was that outside the scope of the article?

item.title: Package Managers Comparison
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

Well, here’s my crap 5 minute job trying to fix that penguin:

Not perfect but it’s better than the other one.

Edit: Didn’t see you had a thread in graphics, lol.

Also, I’d like to point out, on the “Comparison” page, there’s this lovely thing at the bottom:

Contact

If there are any problems or inconsistencies with this website please contact (insert email here)

Thought you’d like to know.

Edit: There’s also a typo on the main page:

The goal of this website is to help its readers choose [b]an[/b] linux-based open-source operating system by examining an integral system utility of any modern linux distribution, the package manager.

Should be “a”.

Read full topic

item.title: Package Managers Comparison
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

What do you mean about the cropping? on what?

About the instructions, I provided everything I could find on the various package managers, rpm is simply lacking functionality that dpkg has (unless you know something I don’t, and that is very possible). I tried to remain as un-biased as possible in the review, although perhaps my predilection for dpkg shows through a bit.

Read full topic

item.title: Package Managers Comparison
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

Interesting and informative.
I would like the image quality to be better and better cropping, as the scraggly crop is distracting. But it is quite informative.
I noticed(since you use Kubuntu, debian based) that you provided more information on deb and dpkg. However you should provide things like installation instructions(like how you did with apt-get) for all of them to be consistent, and to show more of how the complexity and or simplicity is of the managers.
But I would rate it(for documentation and information a 8/10) (for simplicity and access, a 9/10)

Read full topic
